column4: anyone know how rm works? i rm -rf'ed my data directory, and i have a feelign it's still recoverable
rm just unlinks the files from the sfilesystem..  they may or ,may not be recoverable..
if you are wanting to be paranoid theres secure deletion tools out there.
'dd' can copy the mbr to a file and back.. yes.
i find rm works rather well. :)  is tehre some specific problem you are having with it?
if you are worried about the order things get removed.. you could use 'find' and the options it has to remove things in a specific order.
if this is about recovering things.. well.. no idea on that.. good luck undeleting things.
the situation is that i already rm'ed some files... so i want to know what order rm does it in
from what ive seen it does it aplhabetically   make some test dirs and watch the order perhaps?
check the timestamps on the things perhaps  to see when it was last modfied/
thats a great suggestion. otoh, i might also need to do a bitta reading on the rm source code
i'll be darned if google keeps telling me that "rm source code" refers to realmedia... no i do not want to know how realplayer handles streams, thank you
check the apt package manager docs/guides therew a way to get them to download the soruce packages but ive never done so.. and i dont know what package 'rm' is in.
you may want to check out the 'fsarchiver' tool. (but its not in the repos yet)
